awd_titl_txt: The Impact of Network Relational Characteristics on Emerging Small Manufacturing Organizations' Development and Linkages
awd_abstract_narration:
To advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare, this study focuses on the interactions and organizational development among emerging small manufacturing businesses to understand how they develop partnership in order to optimize operational and strategic capabilities to enhance their competitiveness. The investigation focuses on the evolution of innovative U.S. supply chain linkages among six emerging small manufacturing centers developing in rural Colorado communities. Aspects of apparel manufacturing are returning to the U.S. due to the increase in production prices and risks associated with international suppliers.  This research aims to identify ways for small manufacturing businesses to effectively form networks and clusters to gain competitiveness in the market. Findings will have implications for multiple regions of the U.S. interested in cultivating collaborations among small-to-large manufacturing firms. 

The proposals aims to: 1) capture, at multiple levels of analysis, the phenomena involving organizational development of small manufacturers, regional clusters, and a formal network, 2) empirically test overlapping concepts from social capital, network, and innovation theories, and 3) establish a framework to explain how networking develops among emerging small firms.  The scope this project involves the mixed-method study of how six emerging small manufacturing centers organize into two clusters, and then a single network. By focusing on cooperating ventures in which emerging organizations are embedded, the project will discover to what degree network relational characteristics provide a competitive advantage through knowledge creation, learning, and innovation adoption. Data collection involving observations, interviews, focus groups, and survey methods will provide further insights as to the impact of these characteristics on startup firms. The unit of analyses will include the center, cluster, network, and manufacturing levels.  Qualitative and quantitative analyses will be conducted to understand the focal research question of how clusters and networks develop among small manufacturing organizations, and the implications of the clusters and the networks on their market competitiveness.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This study focused on the interactions among small-sized U.S. apparel and sewn products manufacturers to examine relational characteristics that were predicted to enhance operational and strategic capabilities for heightening the reshoring of U.S. apparel production. Aspects of apparel manufacturing have been slowly returning to the U.S. due to the increase in production prices and risks associated with international suppliers. This research examined the contributions of network, knowledge, social capital, and innovation adoption theories for advancing conceptual and practical understanding across the fields of sociology, business, and economics. The intellectual merit of the study involved a focus on cooperating ventures in which interorganizational relationships influenced the firm characteristics, action, and supply chain performance. Broader outcomes from the study hold a two-fold larger societal impact: job creation providing support, particularly for place-bound and low-income individuals; and growth in the U.S. sewn apparel and goods industry that will drive U.S. economy, enhancing quality of life across rural and urban areas. Buying U.S.-made products will contribute to fair wages; reduce foreign dependency; raise quality, consumer protection, and safety standards; reduce the carbon footprint; stabilize the U.S. economic system; reduce the trade deficit; and sustain fair labor standards and child labor laws.

A mixed-method of inquiry was implemented to examine individual firm owners’ perspectives addressing how and with whom they networked, and most importantly what they gained from networking upstream and downstream in the apparel supply chain and how it has impacted their firms’ innovation and performance. In the qualitative phase of the research, interviews and group discussions within a single U.S. region suggested that there was a strong interest in building or extending collaborations along the supply chain.  In the quantitative phase, results from an online survey found network ties were positively impacted by the participating firms’ desire for knowledge and social interactions with similar firms. A subsequent national online survey of small-sized apparel and sewn products manufacturers further emphasized the value of networking with others along the supply chain, and that knowledge building along with network ties held a positive impact on firm product development of innovations. Additional examination found firm performance to be positively influenced by firm owners’ entrepreneurial orientation, interest in new product innovations, and the ability of the firm to acquire knowledge. These empirical insights highlight the importance of building external relationships for generating knowledge in amplifying innovations and firm performance. Findings from this NSF research offer theory building as well as practical implications in recognizing the potential of interacting firm-level entrepreneurial values and behaviors as components contributing to the larger organizational system framework. 

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2022
Modified by: Nancy J Miller
